title: Get Rental History
content: It seems like you might live in a rent stabilized apartment. Request your rental history to make sure.

followUp.title: Do you have any additional concerns about your DHCR letter?

title: Call Tenant Harassment Hotline
content: It looks like you live in an area that experiences a large amount of turnover and harassment and are eligible to call the New York City Tenant Protection Hotline. Hours: Monday – Friday (10AM – 4PM)

followUp.title: What did the anti-harassment hotline say?

title: Call 311
content: It seems like some of your issues might be serious. Calling 311 puts the landlord on notice and courts will take violations more seriously. Be careful of illegal retributions! Please write down the tracking number they give you.

fields.title: Confirmation number:
fields.placeholder: Begins with C1-1-, followed by 9 or 10 numbers.

title: Call NYCHA Help Center
content: If your building manager is unresponsive, call the NYCHA Help Center (open 24/7) and describe your situation, including what you've already done. Please write down the tracking number they give you.

followUp.title: How did your call to NYCHA go?

fields.title: Tracking number:
fields.placeholder: The number you were given to track your Work Order.

title: Call Housing Court Answers
content: Housing Court Answers is a great resource to go for information about legal issues. Hours: Tuesday - Thursday (9AM - 5PM)

title: Connect With an Advocate
content: Find local community groups, legal services, and city hotlines to help with your housing issues.

title: Contact Your Super (Step 1 of 3)
content: Your first step should always be to contact the person directly responsible for making repairs in your home.

title: Email Landlord (Step 2 of 3)
content: If your super is unresponsive, its time to email your landlord. We've drafted an email that you can send, including a list of the issues that need repair.

title: Mail an Official Letter of Complaint (Step 3 of 3)
activityTitle: Created an Official Letter of Complaint
content:
In order to have a formal record of your requests, you need to mail a letter to your landlord. We've drafted a letter that you can send including the repair issues that you've selected.

Make sure to Add Details (located above) first to provide the most detailed information!

title: DHCR Decreased Services App
content: In order to seek a rent reduction for your rent-stabilized apartment, you must submit a formal complaint to DHCR. Use your Case History to fill this form out!

followUp.title: Have you heard back from DHCR yet?

title: HP Action
content: HP Actions are housing court proceedings that offer quick and cheap resolution to repair issues, and legal recourse if your landlord doesn't comply. You must go to the {{user.borough}} Housing Court to file the HP Action.

followUp.title: Did you go to court yet?
